awd_titl_txt: High-Speed, High-Resolution Diagnostic System for a Plasma Wakefield Accelerator
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is aimed towards development of a new diagnostic that will measure the physical processes underlying an advanced particle accelerator concept, a so-called plasma wakefield accelerator (PWFA). PWFA research has the ultimate goal of reducing the footprint, energy consumption, and cost of future particle accelerators by several orders of magnitude for applications ranging from X-ray free electron lasers to high-energy particle colliders.  Currently, no suitable diagnostics for the accelerator plasma source have been developed, and the problem approaches a research bottleneck for the field. The characterization of the plasma source must be non-intrusive and accurate to the few-percent level in order to avoid spoiling the quality of the accelerated electron beam. This necessitates the deployment of diagnostics capable of probing a macroscopic and transient plasma source with percent-level resolution, or better, which lies outside of the application of conventional plasma diagnostic systems.

This project will lay the groundwork for the development of an advanced, integrated system of diagnostic techniques intended to non-intrusively resolve the plasma source density profile (typical density range: 10^15 to 10^18 per cm^3) at the percent level in a single shot, with a spatial resolution of ~mm and a temporal resolution of ~ps. The individual diagnostic sub-systems will be based upon known and proven techniques that are run in tandem with one another to significantly reduce the systematic errors of the full system. The three primary diagnostic sub-systems rely on the principles of Stark broadening, Thomson scattering, and optical emission ("plasma glow"), respectively. The goals of the project are 1) to build detailed models and simulations of the expected signals for each of the diagnostic systems, 2) to test and optimize each system individually using a small, well characterized test plasma source, 3) to integrate all systems and perform simultaneous measurements of the test plasma source, and 4) to develop the analysis framework that combines the data collected by all of the diagnostic systems and minimizes the systematic errors in the recovered plasma density profile. The success of this project will point the way forward for an intended future project that incorporates an imaging spectrometer to provide a single-shot, spatially resolved plasma filament density profile. This will be combined with the use of an ultra-short laser probe pulse, and a fast-gated CCD camera to provide the best possible temporal resolution and signal-to-noise ratio.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to study and identify simple and robust diagnostic techniques that are able to recover the initial density profile of the plasma source for an electron beam-driven plasma wakefield accelerator (PWFA). This is challenging due to the PWFA plasma source’s unique geometry, modest average density, and rapid decay rate. Existing plasma diagnostics for long-lived, low-density fusion plasmas are inappropriate, as are diagnostics for the much smaller and higher density laser-driven plasma wakefield accelerators.

 

The PWFA plasma source is a long (~1 m), narrow (~0.5 mm) filament formed by laser ionization in the middle of a large vacuum chamber filled with low pressure gas (e.g. ~1 Torr of He or Ar) that drops to ~1% of its original density in tens of nanoseconds. Ideally, the electron beam is sent through the PWFA plasma source ~10-100 picoseconds after its formation: well before the plasma has time to evolve. Thus, it is important to diagnose the initial plasma density profile in order to accurately predict the behavior of the plasma acceleration process. The shape, density range, and transient nature of this plasma source make diagnosis a challenge.

 

Multiple diagnostic techniques were investigated over the course of this project, including Thomson scattering, Stark broadening, plasma glow imagery, and laser probe shadowgraphy. The former two proved to be unable to meet our criteria for robustness and reliability, and were discarded. The latter two proved to be both robust and reliable, and complimented each other well to provide the data necessary to reconstruct the initial PWFA plasma source profile. In addition, a custom triple-Langmuir probe was developed and tested and showed promising results. Further development of the probe was deprioritized, however, to devote our resources most efficiently toward the goals of the project.

 

To correctly interpret the experimental signals, a series of simulations were necessary to help us model the plasma formation and subsequent decay process. A combination of home-brew optical simulation codes as well as a commercial fluid dynamics code were used to predict the experimental signatures as a function of the plasma’s initial conditions, concentrating primarily on the average width and core density of the plasma filament. We found that the plasma glow imagery signal was strongly correlated with the initial plasma width. This was somewhat surprising, because the signal is integrated over the entire lifetime of the plasma due to the relatively long exposure time of the camera. We also found that the laser probe shadowgraphy signal—resembling a diffraction pattern—was strongly correlated with the initial plasma filament core density. Thus, these two experimental signals were mostly orthogonal and complimented each other very well. The goal of identifying a simple and robust diagnostic method for the PWFA plasma source was met by using a combination of plasma glow imagery and laser probe shadowgraphy.

 

Though the experimental work has concluded, significant delays to the experimental portion of this project that were due directly or indirectly to COVID-19 (e.g. campus closure and supply chain issues for critical experimental infrastructure) caused the final analysis and writeup of the results to be incomplete by the end of the award period. We anticipate that the final results will be published in a peer-reviewed journal and presented at conferences within roughly six months of the end of the award. Within the next year, the diagnostic techniques developed by this project will be deployed by our research group at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory’s FACET-II research facility for use in a variety of PWFA experiments.

 

During the award period, a total of four undergraduates, one post-bachelor, and two graduate students gained valuable skills and experience through their important contributions to this work. The post-bachelor and two of the undergraduates are now in physics Ph.D. programs, while a third undergraduate is extremely likely to enter a top tier physics Ph.D. program in the next academic year. The experience of working on this project played a large role in their successful entry into grad school. The graduate students who worked on this project have become experts in high power laser systems and associated experimental apparatus and techniques. In addition, the lead graduate student has mastered the laser and plasma physics involved in the research and is the first author on our upcoming publication summarizing the work. She has also presented the work at prominent physics conferences and will do so again in the near future.
